entry.title: Re: Possibilities and Limitations of GROW with SAP - Core...
entry.content:
Hi @Aratrika_Bardhan 

Thank you for your questions. Let me walk you through it.

Below are the Core Functionalities Provided by the Add-On

The basic HR administration and organizational management helps you manage personnel records, job information, organizational structures, and headcount. It provides some self-service for HR teams and employees. Which can include employee data updates, org changes. It also provides some guided business processes and simple workflows such as onboarding/offboarding or record changes. If integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can leverage native connectivity for core ERP HR processes. However, there is limited reporting and analytics on HR data.

The Key Limitations compared to Full SuccessFactors EC

You do not get the full SuccessFactors Employee Central experience, such as advanced talent management, performance reviews, full employee lifecycle, goal, and compensation functions.

You will face fewer configuration and extension options compared to SuccessFactors EC. Add-ons and deep custom workflows may not be possible or are limited.

You do have some simplified set of employee and manager self-services which is limited compared to powerful EC features.

While integration to SAP S/4HANA Cloud and essentials like Payroll or Time Tracking are possible, please note that not all SuccessFactors native integrations or partner apps are available without EC.

Below are you Integration Possibilities

It has the possibility to connects with SAP S/4HANA modules such as core HR, Payroll, and Time Tracking within the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It can also leverage standard APIs for basic data flows.

However, it lacks full SuccessFactors suite integration if EC license is absent. Therefore, making some workflows or analytics limited to a certain extent.

These are Customization and Extensibility possibilities you may consider:

You have the possibility to configure dropdowns, branding, basic business rules, and workflows.

Extensions for example fields or business logic can be added. However, it is important to note that complex workflow or process design is limited compared to EC.

That means it is best for standard HR scenarios and modest customizations and it is not suitable for full enterprise-wide HXM needed by complex organizations.

When Implementing here are considerations and Best Practices to consider:

First is to ensure you clarify your desired scope early enough and ensure client understands what is included and excluded.

Then assess your integration and reporting requirements. If you need deep analytics, workflow automation, or talent management, limitations may require changes to your approach.

In your integration process, you should expect some change management challenges, especially if you are transitioning from full EC or other legacy solutions.

 

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Introducing the GROW with SAP, core HR add-on

entry.title: Re: Origin acceptance fields is not selecting when we use...
entry.content: SAP does not default the "Acceptance at Origin" field based on Incoterms in standard configuration. This is because the field is optional and context-dependent. SAP assumes users will manually set it based on business rules. To automate this and avoid manual effort, you can implement a BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST

entry.title: SBPA Process Scheduler Trigger : A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Welcome back to our SAP Build Process Automation series! In this third blog, we'll dive deep into one of the most crucial aspects of process automation: how to automatically start business processes using scheduler. 

What Are Scheduled Triggers?

Scheduled triggers enable you to automate the initiation of business processes at predefined intervals, eliminating the need for manual intervention or dependency on external events. By defining a time-based schedule, you can ensure that processes run exactly when you want them to, whether that’s daily, weekly, monthly, or following a custom recurrence pattern.

Key Benefits:

  • Hands-free automation – Processes start automatically without user action.
  • Enhanced efficiency – Streamlines operations by reducing delays and human error.
  • Lower manual workload – Frees up resources for higher-value activities.
  • Consistent execution – Ensures tasks run on time, every time.
  • Flexible scheduling – Supports a wide range of recurrence patterns to suit business needs.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  1. Access to SAP Build Process Automation
  2. A working process (we'll use the vendor invoice validation approval process project from previous episodes)
  3. BTP Cockpit access for service key retrieval - trial cockpit

Step-by-Step Implementation 

Phase 1: Project Setup

Step 1: Create a Copy of Your Existing Project from previous blog

  1. Navigate to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Locate your existing project (e.g., "Invoice Validation Approval Process Form")
  3. Select the project by clicking on it
  4. Click "Save As" to create a copy
  5. Enter new project details: 
    1. Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduler 
    2. Description: A invoice validation and approval process scheduler
  6. Click "Save" to create the new project   

Step 2: Access and Prepare the Process

  1. Open the newly created project
  2. Navigate to the process section
  3. You should see:
    • Four forms
    • One process
    •  Existing form scheduler (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)

Phase 2: Removing Existing Process and Adding Scheduled Trigger

Step 3: Remove the Existing Form Process and add the scheduled trigger

  1. Click on the existing form process (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)
  2. Click "Remove" to delete the form
  3. You'll now see a block asking "How do you want to start your process?"
  4. Click "Add a scheduled trigger

Step 4: Create the Scheduled Trigger

  1. Click on "Scheduled Trigger"
  2. Save the process (mandatory before creating Scheduled trigger)
    • Click the Save button
  3. Configure Scheduled Trigger Details: 
    • Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger 
    • Identifier: [Auto-generated - do not modify]
  4. Click "Create"
  5. You'll see a success message: "Scheduled trigger created successfully"  

Phase 3: Configure the Process Inputs

Step 5: Examine Scheduler Trigger Properties

  1. Click on the Scheduler trigger you just created
  2. Review Output Fields:
  • These are automatically synchronized from process inputs
  • Fields include: Vendor Name, Invoice Number, Invoice Date, Vendor Email, Invoice Amount, Due Date

Phase 4: Project Release and Deployment 

Step 6: Release the Project

  1. Save all changes
  2. Click "Release" button in the top toolbar
  3. Confirm the release when prompted
  4. Wait for successful release message

Click on the "Release" button, add the release notes (Optional) and click on the Release.

Step 7: Deploy the Project

  1. Click "Deploy" button (appears after release)
  2. Select target environment (typically "Public Environment")
  3. Confirm deployment
  4. Wait for deployment completion
  5. Note the deployment success message

Phase 5: Accessing Deployment Information 

Step 8: Navigate to Control Tower

  1. Go to SAP Build Lobby home
  2. Click on "Control Tower"
  3. Navigate to "Tenant Configuration"
  4. Click on "Environments"
  5. Select "Public Environment" (or your deployment target)

Step 9: Locate Your Deployed Project

  1. Find your project: "Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger"
  2. Click on the project name
  3. Navigate to "Triggers" tab
  4. Locate: "Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger"

Phase 6: Configure the Scheduled Trigger

Step 10: Activate the Trigger

  1. Click on the three dots under Actions
  2. Select "Activate"

Step 11: Schedule Configuration

  1. Schedule Tab Settings
    1. Date Range: August 14th, 2025 to August 25th, 2026 (1-month subscription)
    2. Time Zone: IST (Indian Standard Time)
    3. Recurrence: 5 month (monthly execution)
    4. Start Time: 9:43 MM
    5. Day Number: 1st day of every month
  2. Recurrence Options Available
    1. Minutes: Maximum 59 minutes
    2. Hours: Maximum 24 hours
    3. Days: Maximum 7 days
    4. Weeks: Maximum 35 weeks
    5. Months: Maximum 12 months

Step 12: Input Parameters

  1. Configure Input Data
    1. Switch to "Input Parameter" tab
    2. Enter the following sample data:
      1. Vendor Name
      2. Invoice Number
      3. Invoice Date
      4. Vendor Email
      5. Invoice Amount
      6. Due Date
  2. Activate Configuration
    1. Click "Activate"
    2. The trigger will be successfully updated

Phase 7: Testing and Monitoring

Step 13: Test Immediate Execution

  • After activation, you'll see new options under "Actions":
    • Disable trigger
    • Run now (for testing)
    • Edit trigger configuration
  • Click "Run now" for testing

Step 14: Monitor Process Instance

  1. Return to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to "Monitoring"
  3. Click "Process and Workflow Instances"
  4. Locate your new process instance:
    • Status: Running
    • Instance ID: [Auto-generated]
    • Started by: Scheduled Trigger

Step 15: Review Process Data

  1. Click on the process instance
  2. Review "Process Details":
    • Vendor Name: TEST VENDOR
    • Invoice Number: 1234
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Vendor Email: test-vendor@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-16

    3. Check process flow: Should be waiting for approval

Step 16: Review all the details and Approve the process form

Step 17: Verify Process Completion

  1. Return to "Process and Workflow Instances"
  2. Refresh the page
  3. Check your process instance:
    • Status: Completed
    • All approval messages visible
    • Complete process flow executed 

Conclusion

Scheduled triggers in SAP Build Process Automation offer a robust and flexible way to automate recurring business processes without manual intervention.

Through the vendor invoice validation approval prcess example, we see how such triggers can streamline operations, maintain consistency, and enhance efficiency by executing workflows at precise intervals. By carefully configuring schedules, input parameters, and approval steps, organizations can reduce errors, optimize resources, and scale their automation efforts.

However, success depends on thorough testing, proper security measures, and continuous monitoring to ensure reliability and performance in production environments.

entry.title: Re: Absence Counting Rules 2.0 in Time Management - 2H 2023
entry.content:
Hello @PriyankaAgarwal,

Thanks for the detailed blog addressing all possible scenarios.

I was working on a requirement that you mentioned as sandwich rule, wherein we are required to count the weekly offs when they fall in between the start and end dates of the time off request.

In the the If condition, I checked for the start date and end date falling on the working days using the Day of Week function, then setting the weekly offs to 1. This is working good as of now.

However, if there are many workschedules that have varying weekly offs, probably we need to enhance the rule to include more blocks in the counting rule considering the fact that this is not exposed to lookups. Would this be a good approach? 

Thanks

Pradeep

entry.title: Automation Pilot を使った Cloud Foundry 上のアプリの夜間停止と再起動の構築手順
entry.content:
はじめに

SAP BTPのCloud Foundry環境で稼働するカスタムアプリケーションですが、リソース最適化の観点から夜間は停止させたいというケースも考えられます。そこで、BTP上で提供されるローコード／ノーコードの運用自動化サービスであるAutomation Pilot を活用して、「夜間にアプリを停止し、朝に再起動する」ための構築手順を紹介します。

想定読者は、Cloud FoundryやBTPには馴染みがあるが、Automation Pilotを初めて利用する方となっています。

1. CatalogとInputの作成

最初にCatalogを作成します。

  • Catalog: CommandとInputをまとめるフォルダのような単位で、プロジェクトごとにまとめて管理できます。

今回は 'Sample' という名前を付けます。

 次に、Cloud Foundryアプリを操作するためのInputを作成します。

  • Input: Commandで使う設定値をKey-Value形式でまとめて管理できます。

Input名は 'CfAppOperation' とします。

Inputには、認証情報と対象アプリを特定するための情報を登録します。

  • user : BTPのテクニカルユーザー名
  • password : ユーザーのパスワード (Sensitive設定ON推奨)
  • region : Cloud Foundryリージョン名 (例:  cf-eu10)
  • subAccount : サブアカウント名
  • resourceGroup : スペース名
  • resourceName : アプリケーション名 (例. cap-js-bookshop-srv)

このようにInputとして一度登録しておくと、停止・再起動のCommand実行時に毎回入力する手間が省けます。

2. 停止Command の作成

次に、アプリを停止するためのCommandを作成します。

  • Command: Automation Pilot における実行可能な処理の単位で、開始時にInput Keysを受け取り、終了時にOutput Keysを返します。Commandは他のCommandを順に組み合わせて構成されます。

作成するCommand名を 'StopCfApp' とし、Catalogとして先ほどの 'Sample' を指定します。

CommandにExecutorを追加します。

  • Executor: Commandの中で利用される一つあるいは複数のCommandを含んだラッパーです。対象Commandを正しく実行できるようにInput Keysに値を与える必要があり、その値は直接指定するかDynamic Expressionで参照できます。

Executorは'StopApplication'というエイリアスを設定し、事前定義済みの 'applm-sapcp'の'StopCfApp' を選択します。

'StopApplication'で表示されている 'applm-sapcp:StopCfApp:1' をクリックして、情報を見てみます。

InputとOutputのKey-Valueの定義がそれぞれ確認できます。これらの情報をもとに、後述のInput KeysとOutput Keysを設定します。

先ほどのページに戻り、Input Keysを定義します。passwordはSensitive設定ONが推奨です。

最終的に、以下の6つのKeyをInput Keysとして設定します。

先ほど作成したInput Keysを'StopApplication'のParametersとDynamic Expressionで紐付けます。

続いて、Output Keysを定義します。

最終的には下記のようなOutput Keysを作成します。

Output Keysも同様に、StopApplicationの出力とDynamic Expressionで紐付けます。

下記のようになります。

3. 動作確認

ここまでで、停止用Commandが完成しました。画面右上の Trigger ボタンから実行し、結果を確認します。

実行結果画面の Output > Show をクリックすると、対象アプリ（例: cap-js-bookshop-srv）が停止されたことが確認できます。エラーが出た場合は、Input設定、権限、値の紐付けなどを再確認してください。

4. スケジュール設定

次に、この停止Commandを自動的に定期実行するためにスケジュール設定を行います。

スケジュール対象として、'StopCfApp'を選択します。

ここでは、東京のタイムゾーンで毎日22時に実行するように設定します。

'StopCfApp'をスケジュールできました。

5. 再起動Commandの設定

朝の稼働時間にアプリを再起動させるため、停止と同様の手順で再起動Commandを設定します。

ここでは事前定義済みの 'applm-sapcp:RestartCfApp' を利用します。停止時と同様にInputを紐付け、スケジュールを「毎日朝7時」などに設定すれば、夜間停止したアプリを自動的に再起動するようになります。

終わりに

本記事では、Automation Pilotを使ってCloud Foundry上のアプリを夜間停止し、朝に再起動させる手順を紹介しました。ポイントは以下の通りです。

  • Inputとして認証情報とアプリ情報を管理
  • 事前定義済みCommand（StopCfApp / RestartCfApp）を利用
  • 値の紐付けを行う
  • スケジューリング機能で定期実行

今回は再現性の担保の観点から一つ一つGUIで設定して行きましたが、生成AI機能を活用することでより効率的にCommandの作成ができます。

また、応用として、停止・再起動のメール通知、対象アプリケーションの拡充なども可能です。

日々の運用を効率化する第一歩として、ぜひ試してみてください！

entry.title: RFUI: Default Presentation Device field – Enter key does not trigger submit on mobile (Velocity)
entry.content:
We are using the RFUI (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition Warehouse Management) to log on with fields Warehouse, Resource and Default Presentation Device.

  • On desktop browsers (Chrome): after filling Resource and pressing Enter, the system validates the entry and automatically fills the Default Presentation Device (based on customizing Resource → Default Presentation Device). Pressing Enter again continues the logon.

  • On mobile devices (Zebra scanners with Android + Chrome/Velocity): pressing Enter after filling Resource does not trigger validation. As a result:

    • The Default Presentation Device is not automatically filled, even though customizing exists.

    • Pressing Enter in the Default Presentation Device field also does not trigger submit; users are forced to press the OK button.

This leads to inconsistent behavior: desktop Enter = submit, mobile Enter = no action.

Impact:

  • Users on scanners cannot log in by pressing Enter (physical keyboard & virtual keyboard), which breaks standard RF process flows.

Expected behavior:

  • Enter key should trigger the same validation/submit on mobile as it does on desktop.

  • Resource → Default Presentation Device assignment should work identically on both desktop and mobile.

Possible fix:

  • Using Ivanti Velocity Console, we can remap the hardware/software Enter key (keycode 66) to Tab or OK event. This forces the validation/submit to trigger, and the Default Presentation Device is then filled. Could this be the solution?

Request to SAP:

  • Please confirm if this difference is a known limitation (by design) in RFUI.

  • If so, provide the relevant SAP Note or documentation.

  • If not, we kindly request a correction so that the Enter key on Android/Velocity is handled the same as on desktop browsers (triggering validation and form submit).

Scope

Should this be in scope of the suppliers of the scanners (they imaged the scanners) of is this in scope of functional SAP consultants.

entry.title: はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - 差異の表示
entry.content:
本ブログシリーズはSAP Analytics CloudのBI機能を使ってダッシュボードやレポートの作成を行う方を対象とし、SAP Analytics CloudのBIにおける基本の操作やTipsをハンズオン形式でご紹介します。

本ブログでは、ストーリーにて予実差異を表示したい！前年度差異をぱっとわかるようにしたい！といった方向けに、以下のようにチャートやテーブルにおいて差異を表示する方法についてご紹介します。

目次：

  • SAP Analytics Cloudにおける差異表示
  • チャートでの差異の追加方法［ハンズオン］
  • テーブルでの差異の追加方法［ハンズオン］

※ベースとなるサンプルストーリーの作成手順は、はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityでご紹介しています。

※ SAP Analytics Cloudは、四半期に１度のペースで製品のバージョンアップが実施されます。そのため今後のバージョンアップにより、本ブログで紹介する画面キャプチャや、操作が異なる可能性があることをご了承ください。（本ブログは2025年5月に作成しています。）

SAP Analytics Cloudにおける差異表示

SAP Analytics Cloudにおける差異表示は大きく2種類：チャートでの差異表示とテーブルでの差異計算列の追加による表示があります。

チャートでの差異表示では、複数のバージョン間での差異、または複数の期間における差異を値またはパーセントで表示することができます。差異の表現方法は、チャートによって

【画像】
詳細はヘルプページをご覧ください：チャートに対する差異の追加 | SAP Help Portal

テーブルでの差異計算列の追加による表示では、XXX
【画像】
詳細はヘルプページをご覧ください：（ヘルプリンク）

チャートでの差異の追加方法［ハンズオン］

0. (リンク)で作成したストーリーを編集モードで開こう！

0.1. ナビゲーションバーのファイルより作成したストーリーを開き、「編集」をクリックします。

1. 数値ポイントのチャートに、前年度との差異を追加しよう！

※2025年Q3より数値ポイントのUIが変わりました。本ブログは変更前の画像になります。

1.1. 数値ポイントチャートをクリックした上、右パネル（ビルダパネル）を開きます。

1.2. （2025年の第2四半期にフィルタをかけます。）「＋フィルタの追加」をクリックします。

1.3. 「Data（メンバー）」をクリックします。

1.4. 「2025」を展開して「Q2」を選択し、「OK」をクリックします。（2025年の第2四半期にフィルタがかかりました。）

1.5. ビルダパネルの「チャートアドオン」を展開し、「差異」をクリックします。

1.6. 「＋バージョン/時間の追加」をクリックします。

1.7. 「Date」を選択します。（今回は前年度差異のためDateを選択しましたが、予実差異の場合はバージョンを選択します。）

1.8. TO (B)の時間にて、「前の時間間隔」の「ｖ」をクリックします。

1.9. 「前年度」を選択します。（これにより、2025Q1との比較から2024Q2との比較に変更されました。）

1.10. 表示オプションの差異の表示形式を「パーセント」に変更します。

1.11. 前年度差異を％で表すチャートが完成しました！

2. 棒チャートに、予算と実績の差異を追加しよう！

2.1.
2.2.
2.3.

テーブルでの差異の追加方法［ハンズオン］

3. テーブルにXXX

 

今回は差異チャートのご紹介でした。SAP Analytics Cloudは他にも様々な表現や便利な機能があり、本ブログシリーズでご紹介しています。（まとめ）のリンクからご参照ください。

entry.title: Budget is returned to available during the GR posting for PO's with acc assig “A” (Asset)
entry.content:
Dear Experts

We are Facing an issue when posting the Goods Receipt (GR) for purchase orders with account assignment type “A” (Asset). Upon posting via Movement Type 101, the system releases the committed and assigned budget back to availability. This behavior enables users to create additional purchase orders under the same WBS element using the same budget potentially without restriction.

The issue is that the system does not capture the WBS element already assigned to the asset during the GR posting. As a result, no CO document is generated, and the budget control mechanism fails to consume the allocated funds.

Notably:

  • Cost Element Category 90 is active.
  • The G/L Account linked to the relevant asset class has the “Record Account Assignment” field enabled in Transaction Code FS00.
  • The account assignment objects in Asset Accounting are maintained via Transaction Code ACSET.

Despite these configurations, the system fails to derive the WBS element during the initial GR posting Movement Type 101

However, when the GR is reversed using Movement Type 102, the system correctly captures the WBS element, generates the corresponding CO document, and transfers the budget to the actuals with a negative value indicating that the integration logic functions correctly in reversal scenarios.

Thank you advance

Best Regard

entry.title: Automatically Stop and Restart Your Cloud Foundry App Overnight with Automation Pilot
entry.content:
Introduction

When you run custom applications in the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Runtime, it may be smart, purely from a resource-optimization standpoint, to shut them down at night and start them again in the morning. In this post, you’ll learn how to implement a 'stop at night, restart in the morning' routine by using Automation Pilot, SAP BTP’s low-/no-code automation service for operations.

This guide targets readers who already know Cloud Foundry and SAP BTP, but who are using Automation Pilot for the first time.

1. Create a Catalog and an Input

You start by creating a Catalog.

  • Catalog: Groups of Commands and Inputs so you can manage them per project.

For this tutorial, create a Catalog called 'Sample'.

Next, create an Input for operating your Cloud Foundry app.

  • Input: A reusable collection of key-value pairs that Commands can access at runtime.

Create an Input named 'CfAppOperation'.

Add the following information to the Input so you can authenticate and locate the target app:

  • user - BTP technical user
  • password - Password (set Sensitive = ON is recommended)
  • region - Cloud Foundry region (ex. cf-eu10)
  • subAccount - Sub-account name
  • resourceGroup - Space name
  • resourceName - Application name (ex. cap-js-bookshop-srv)

Registering this information once as an Input saves you from typing it every time you run a stop or restart Command.

2. Create the Stop Command

Now you create the Command that actually stops the app.

  • Command: A runnable unit in Automation Pilot. It consumes Input Keys when it starts and returns Output Keys when it finishes. Commands themselves can be built from other Commands.

Create a new Command named 'StopCfApp' in the 'Sample' Catalog.

Add an Executor to the Command.

  • Executor: A wrapper that holds one or more Commands. Supply values for the underlying Command’s Input Keys - either hard-coded or via Dynamic Expressions.

Set the Executor’s alias to 'StopApplication' and choose the predefined Command 'applm-sapcp'の'StopCfApp'. 

Click the link to 'applm-sapcp:StopCfApp:1' to inspect its Input and Output Keys.

You can see the definitions of Input and Output Keys here. Use these details to configure the Input Keys and Output Keys in the next steps.

On the previous screen, create six Input Keys. Remember to mark password as Sensitive.

In the end, you should have the following six Input Keys.

Map each Input Key to the corresponding parameters of 'StopApplication' with Dynamic Expressions.

Next, define the Output Keys.

The Output Keys has to be look like below:

Map each Output Key to the outputs of 'StopApplication' via Dynamic Expressions.

It should look like this:

3. Test the Command

Your stop Command is now complete. Click the Trigger button in the upper-right corner of the screen to run it.

On the execution-result screen, choose Output > Show to confirm that the target app (e.g., cap-js-bookshop-srv) was stopped. If errors appear, recheck your Input settings, permissions, key mappings and so on.

4. Set Up a Schedule

Schedule the 'StopCfApp' Command so it runs automatically.

Select 'StopCfApp' as the target Command.

For example, schedule it to run every day at 22:00 (10 p.m.) Japanese time.

'StopCfApp' is now on a schedule.

5. Create the Restart Command

Repeat the same steps to create a restart Command, but choose the predefined Command 'applm-sapcp:RestartCfApp'. Link it to the same Input and schedule it, say at 07:00, so the app starts automatically each morning.

Conclusion

You have now used Automation Pilot to stop a Cloud Foundry app overnight and bring it back online every morning. Key takeaways:

  • Store authentication and app details in an Input
  • Leverage predefined Commands (StopCfApp / RestartCfApp)
  • Map Input and Output Keys correctly
  • Use schedules for recurring execution

While this tutorial walked through the GUI step-by-step for reproducibility, you can speed things up with Automation Pilot’s generative-AI features and extend the flow—for example, by sending email notifications when the app stops or restarts, or by applying the same logic to multiple applications.

Give it a try and take a step toward more efficient daily operations!

entry.title: Re: Budget is returned to available during the GR posting...
entry.content:
If I am correct, SAP does not support WBS element derivation for balance sheet accounts (like asset-related G/Ls) with cost element category 90 during GR posting. This means the WBS element assigned to the asset is not automatically transferred during GR. The CO document is skipped, and budget consumption fails. The system treats the GR as a stock capitalization, not a cost consumption.

What you can do is review whether budget consumption should occur at invoice posting instead of GR for asset-related POs. Alternatively, consider a BAdI MB_DOCUMENT_BADI or substitution logic to inject the WBS element manually during GR

entry.title: Re: Configuration of Technical Account for Advanced Forei...
entry.content:
Hi @AlvaroFernandezMorales 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

Please note that SAP S/4HANA Cloud's Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation posts valuation adjustments directly to the same reconciliation account as your original open item, based on the system’s configuration for FX accounts. There is no standard configuration option within Advanced Valuation to post revaluation differences to a separate technical account. This is because postings are always made to the account being valuated, which is typically the original reconciliation account.

Here are a few reasons and key points you should take note of:

In reference to the point made earlier, you can only specify realized and unrealized gain or loss accounts for your P&L but not an alternative technical balance sheet account for the valuation adjustment itself.

This limitation is part of SAP's design for the Advanced Valuation solution in S/4HANA Cloud and is confirmed in both SAP documentation.

To work around this, I advice to consider the following:

If your business requires adjustment postings to a different technical account, you will need a custom posting process such as journal entries or additional closing routines. It is important to note that standard configuration does not support this feature.

To summarise, advanced Foreign Currency Valuation in S/4HANA Cloud does not offer a way to redirect valuation postings to a separate technical account. Postings are always made to the original account to be valuated. For your requirement, I suggest you consider discussing custom solutions with your SAP implementation partner.

I hope this provides clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to maintain more add-On Product Versions to the c...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

To have more add-on product versions maintained for your system, you need to edit the system in SAP for Me -> System application.

Kindly refer to the KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/2241656 for the steps to maintain system data in SAP for Me.

And as KBA 2241656 mentioned, to edit and maintain system data, S-user needs the following authorizations:

  • Display System Data authorization is required to view system data
  • Edit System Data authorization is required to edit or maintain system data

If you don't have the above mentioned authorizations, kindly request for the missing authorizations via the Self-Service authorization request function per KBA 2891528.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Publish MQTT Messages on Dynamic Broker Topics
entry.content:
Publish MQTT Messages on Dynamic Broker Topics

Publishing MQTT messages on message brokers from SAP Digital Manufacturing has become more flexible. Learn how to use dynamic broker topics to publish MQTT messages to broker topics that are only known at runtime. We’ll walk you through different scenarios and explain the configuration.

Introduction

With release 2508 of SAP Digital Manufacturing (DM), publishing and subscribing to topics on third-party MQTT brokers has become more flexible due to the following changes:

  • Removal of the “Topics” table in the “Manage Message Broker” app: In previous releases, you had to enter each topic to publish or subscribe to from a given production connector into a table and specify whether the topic could be used for publishing, subscribing or both. This represented a limitation in cases where the topic was only known at runtime, for example, topics including a serial number or order number to associate a published message via the topic name to an applicable manufacturing execution context.
  • Free text entry of topic names in the “Manage Automatic Triggers” app: In earlier releases, when creating subscriptions, you had to select topics to subscribe and publish to from a dropdown list that included the topics as defined in the “Topics” table. With the removal of the “Topics” table, the dropdown lists in the subscription UIs have been replaced with free text fields.
  • Support of expressions for the topic parameter in the “Publish MQTT Message” service: The “Publish MQTT Message” service is a built-in service available for automation sequences in the “Design Production Processes” app. The topic to publish a message to is one of the payload parameters of this service. Previously, it only offered a dropdown list to select a topic from the “Topics” table, now, it supports expressions that can be composed with the expression editor. You can use it to concatenate the following types of strings:
    • Static strings for prefix, suffix, or slashes, like "Test/" or "/".
    • Start parameters of the automation sequence, such as 'sensorID'.
    • Global variables, for example, a field “SFC” contained in a structure “ME_Context” defining the global variable, like 'Service_readGlobalVariables#ME_Context["DME_SFC"]'.
    • The elements of the string are concatenated via the &-operator available in the expression editor.
    • The expression is limited to a maximum length of 255 characters, which can be converted at runtime on the Production Connector to a topic name with a length of up to 65535 bytes.

 In the following sections, we would like to illustrate in few examples how this new freedom can be used to add value to customers using MQTT brokers on their shop floor.

 Flow at Runtime

The flow for all three scenarios is quite similar. A payload containing a reading from a temperature sensor will be enriched with applicable manufacturing execution (ME) context including information like plant, work center, production order, operation, material, SFC and eventually published to a dynamic broker topic that is determined at runtime. In the example, the broker topic is Test/<SFC>/<sensorID>, this is a concatenation of the string “Test/”, the string value of SFC that has been processed at the point in time when the sensor reading was taken, the string “/” and the ID of the sensor that took the temperature reading.

In all three example scenarios, the ME context is written to a design-wide global variable that resides on the Production Connector runtime that is connected to the MQTT broker. This is done by a cloud process that hands over the current values of the variable fields to an automation sequence that writes them to the global variable. The global variable is stored on the Windows file system the Production Connector runs on.

 Depending on the use case, the cloud process can be started by a production operator dashboard (POD), a business rule, or by a web service call handing over the current ME context for the global variable as start parameters of the cloud process.

For all three scenarios, the same automation sequence is used to publish the sensor reading enriched with the applicable ME context to the broker topic that is dynamically determined at runtime as described earlier. The raw data of the sensor reading – in the example consisting of the temperature reading, timestamp, and sensor ID – is handed over as start parameters to the automation sequence, which then reads the ME context and combines the data in the message that is eventually published to the applicable broker topic.

Note that the ME context stored with global variable and the sensor readings are only implicitly linked with each other. The fields included in the definition of global variable containing ME context, the events triggering the cloud process to update the global variable, and the location of the sensor must be chosen appropriately so that sensor reading and the values of the global variable at that point in time are correctly correlated to each other. The intention of this blog is to provide an example. Depending on the concrete layout of your shop floor it may need to be adapted.

Depending on the concrete use case, the published messages with the enriched sensor readings can be consumed for advanced analytics such as Golden Batch analysis and other.

In the example, we examine three different sources for the sensor data:

  1. The temperature sensor acts as an MQTT client and publishes its readings to a static broker topic – in the example  RawData. In SAP Digital Manufacturing, a MQTT subscription triggers the automation sequence mentioned earlier and hands over the sensor reading as start parameters.
  2. The temperature sensor makes its readings available as tag changes on an OPC UA server. In SAP Digital Manufacturing, an indicator subscription triggers the automation sequence and hands over the sensor reading as start parameters.
  3. The automation sequence is exposed as a RESTful service endpoint with the Production Connector acting as the RESTful service provider. In this case, the temperature sensor acts as a web client and includes its reading as payload to the request body when calling the endpoint.

In the rest of the article, we’ll walk you through the configuration of the first two scenarios. We’ll focus on the required steps to set up the connection to the MQTT broker, configuration of the message subscription and publishing to dynamic topics. For the handling of the global variable, I’ll refer to my earlier blogs.

 We're currently working on another blog that dives deep into a new feature coming with the 2511 release. This feature allows you to turn the Production Connector into a RESTful service provider and expose automation sequences as REST services callable from Web clients residing on your shop floor. In this planned article, we will tackle the third scenario mentioned above as an example and explain the required configuration in detail. You can expect it to appear soon.

Overview of the required configuration steps

The configuration consists of the following steps:

1. Create a design-wide global variable of the structure data type and choose “DME_Shopfloor” for its schema or any other schema you’ve created that contains fields needed for the relevant ME context for your use case.

2. Create a production process design with an automation sequence that writes its start parameters to the fields of the global variable created in step 1.

3. Create a production process in the cloud with start parameters matching the start parameters of the automation sequence. Add the automation sequence created in step 2 as a subprocess to the cloud process. Save, deploy and activate your design so that you can test writing example values to the global variable. These values will be used later for enriching the sensor readings. During our test we have used the values “SFC120815”, “Chocolate Drink”, “1234”, “Mixing”, “MIXING” and “1010” for the fields “SFC”, “Material”, “OrderNo”, “Operation”, WorkCenter”, and “PlantID”, respectively.


For the configuration details on these three steps, refer to steps 1 and 2 of the  configuration section in my earlier blog “Automate your Data Collections with 3rd-Party MQTT Brokers”. Step 3 from above is quite similar to step 4 in the other blog, where an automation sequence to read a global variable is called from the cloud process. Make sure that you set the toggle “Publish to Service Registry” in the header settings of your production process in the cloud. Otherwise, it will not be available as an action when you set up your MQTT subscription a later step. Then continue as follows:

4. Create a digital twin for your message broker in the “Manage Message Broker” app.

5. Connect you Production Connector to the message broker and establish a trust relation between them. It needs to be the same Production Connector that the automation sequence created in step (2) runs on.

6. Create a message payload schema containing all the fields of your message with enriched sensor data.

7. Add another automation sequence to the design (and Production Connector) created in step 1. The start parameters of the automation sequence need to match the three fields of the sensor reading (temperature, timestamp, and sensor ID). Add the built-in services “Read Global Variables” and “Publish MQTT Message” and configure their payload parameters. Configure the “Topic” field to support dynamic topics.

 You can now save, deploy, and activate the new version of your design and test it.

 Steps 1-7 are common to all three scenarios. Let’s continue with the specifics of scenario 1 and 2. Create subscriptions in the “Manage Automatics Triggers” app to trigger the automation sequence created in step (7) as new sensor readings arrive:

Scenario 1: Create a subscription of type “message” that listens on the static broker topic your temperature sensor acting as an MQTT client is publishing its readings to. As an action, select the automation sequence from step 7 and map the message fields to the start parameters of the automation sequence. You don’t need to model an asset as a digital twin of your sensor.

Scenario 2: As your sensor writes its readings as tags to an OPC UA server, you need to model a digital twin for your sensor in the production connectivity model (PCM) in SAP Digital Manufacturing first, before you can create a subscription of type “indicator” that triggers the automation sequence from step 7. This requires three steps:

  1. Create a shop floor system of type OPC UA as a digital twin for your OPC UA server in the “Configure Production Connectivity” app.
  2. Create a digital twin for your sensor in the “Manage Assets” app.
  3. Map the indicators of the digital twin modeled in step ii to tags of the OPC UA server in the “Manage Asset Connectivity” app.

Let’s examine the details of these configuration steps starting with step 4.

Create a digital twin for your MQTT broker

Open the “Manage Message Brokers” app, choose “Third-Party Brokers” and then Create. Enter the name, description, host name and port of your message broker and upload the public part of the server certificate of your broker (or the trust chain of that server certificate) to establish a secure connection to your broker.

Connect your Production Connector with your message broker

Continue in the “Manage Message Brokers” app by choosing the “Production Connector” tab. Choose “Add” and select your Production Connector from the list of the available production connectors in your DM tenant. It will add the selected production connector to the (before empty) list of production connectors that are connected to your message broker. Enter the detail view of the added production connector. Here, you need to either generate a self-signed client certificate for your production connector or upload a client certificate that was created from a trusted certification authority (CA) / trust center. For a productive tenant, we strongly recommend the latter. Note that, in the case of uploading the certificate, only the PEM format is supported. In your third-party broker, don’t forget to upload the public part of the self-signed certificate or, alternatively, the trust-chain of intermediate certificates and the root certificates of the CA that issued the client certificate so that your message broker can trust the production connector connecting to it.

Choose Update, and then Save. In our example, the connection of our production connector “Partnertest07” to our broker “WDF1_MOSQUITTO” shows up as “Deployed”.

Create Message Payload Schema

Navigate in the launchpad to the “Manage Service Registry” app and choose the “Schema” tab. Here, you need to create the schema for the message with the enriched sensor data you want to publish.

Choose Create, give a name and choose “Switch to Code”:

Replace the skeleton code you find in the code view by the following schema (you can adapt it to your use case, of course):

{
 "type": "object",
 "title": "MQTT_Sensor_Enriched_Reading--00001",
 "properties": {
   "SFC": {
       "format": "",
       "description": "Plant ID",
        "type": "string"
    },
    "temperature": {
       "format": "",
       "description": "temperature reading from sensor",
       "type": "string"
    },
    "Material": {
        "format": "",
        "description": "Material",
        "type": "string"
    },
    "OrderNo": {
        "format": "",
        "description": "Number of Production Order",
        "type": "string"
    },
    "Operation": {
        "format": "",
        "description": "Plant ID",
        "type": "string"
    },
    "WorkCenter": {
         "format": "",
         "description": "SensorWorkCenter",
         "type": "string"
    },
    "PlantID": {
         "format": "",
         "description": "Plant ID",
         "type": "string"
    },
    "timestamp": {
          "description": "sensor timestamp",
          "type": "string",
           "title": ""
     },
     "sensorID": {
            "default": "unknown_sensor",
            "format": "",
            "description": "sensor ID",
            "type": "string"
      }
   }
}

Then, choose Create.

Create an automation sequence to enrich & publish the sensor reading

You need to create the automation sequence in the same design and on the same production connector you connected with your broker as explained in the section right above. It needs to be the same production connector that hosts the automation sequence that writes the global variable you created in step 2. The reason for the latter is that design-wide global variables are only accessible for automation sequences included in the same production process design and that run on the same runtime – here the production connectors connecting as MQTT client to your message broker.

Therefore, in that design create an automation sequence with the two built-in services “Read Global Variables” and “Publish MQTT Message”:

Select the start control and choose “Manage Parameters” to add start parameters for your automation sequence:

Add the three parameters “temperature”, “timestamp”, and “sensorID” – all of type string to keep it simple for now and choose Save.

Select the built-in service “Read Global Variable”, which you have previously dragged in from the left “Services and Processes” pane into the central canvas. Don’t forget to connect the Start control, the two built-in services and the End control with arrows representing the process flow. The payload parameters of the selected built-in service appear on the right pane. Choose Add and select the global variable to read:

The name of the global variable – in our example “ME_Context” should now show up on the right pane.

Select the built-in service “Publish MQTT Message” in the central canvas. Its payload parameters appear on the right pane. Select your message broker (here “WDF1_MOSQUITTO”).

Now, it is time to configure the dynamic topic to publish the message to. Choose the payload field “Topic” and then “Open expression editor”. Here we will concatenate the elements that make up the dynamic topic: Test/<SFC>/<sensorID>. “Test/” and “/” are static strings. <SFC> is a field of the structure ME_Context that defines the read global variable. Lastly, <sensorID> is a start parameter of the automation sequence. We start entering “Test/” into the expression editor. Then, we select the “&-operator” to concatenate the next element <SFC>:

We can select the global variable from the Functions and Variables:

This will result in the following expression, which does not yet contain the field “DME_SFC”:

Here ends the support of the expression editor and you need to add the string ["DME_SFC"] manually so that it results in "Test/" &'Service_readGlobalVariables#ME_Context["DME_SFC"]'.

Make sure that you are using single and double quotes in these expressions, and nothing else. Don’t confuse them with ‘, “”. Next, we need to add & "/" & before we can select the start parameter sensorID from the expression editor again:

 You should end up with the following expression for the dynamic topic:

"Test/" &'Service_readGlobalVariables#ME_Context["DME_SFC"]' & "/" & 'sensorID'

Choose OK to close the expression editor. You can keep the Quality of Service (QoS) default setting of “0 – At Most Once” or change it to your requirements.

As “Message Payload Data Type” you need to select “Structure” and then select the “Message Payload Schema” you’ve created in step 6.

Now, choose the icon next to the “Message Payload” field and define the message payload by mapping start parameters of the automation sequence and fields from the global variable “ME_Context” respectively:

You design should now look as follows:

Choose Save All and Quick Deploy. If an error appears, choose “Go to deployment group”. This is a precautional step to prevent the user from accidentally deactivating runtime artifacts and disrupting production on the shop floor. Therefore, you must deactivate them manually first:

Now, you can select “Deploy and Activate” on the same screen again and it should successfully deploy and activate the automation sequences on your production connector:

Choose Back on the top left to return to your design. Choose Run to test your automation sequence:

 

However, before choosing Run, you need to have a MQTT client connected to your broker with a subscription to the top-level topic “Test/#”. We are using MQTTX:

When choosing Run, the enriched message containing the sensor reading combined with the ME context that you’ve previously written to your global variable should appear in MQTTX.

Observe the topic the message was published to. It has been correctly computed from the expression previously defined: Test/SFC120815/sensor02. The SFC written to the global variable is SFC120815, and the sensorID is sensor02.

Scenario 1: Create a subscription of type “message”

 We will tackle now the part of the configuration that is specific to the first scenario where the temperature sensor acts as an MQTT client and publishes its readings to a static broker topic “RawData”. We assume that its messages are published as a JSON structure as follows:

 {
  "type": "object",
   "title": "MQTT_Sensor_v2",
    "properties": {
          "temperature": {
          "format": "",
           "description": "",
           "type": "string"
          },
          "sensorID": {
          "format": "",
          "description": "",
          "type": "string"
          },
          "timestamp": {
          "format": "",
          "description": "",
           "type": "string"
          }
      }
}

You need to create it as a schema for the sensor payload structure in the “Manage Service Registry” app in the same way as described in the “Create Message Payload Schema” section above for the message structure used for the enriched sensor data.

Then, you can use it when you create the subscription of type “message” in the “Manage Automatic Triggers” app. Select, your broker (here WDF1_MOSQUITTO), production connector (here partnertest07), static topic to subscribe to (here Rawdata – needs to be without a “/” at the end), “Quality of Service” (here 0 – At Most Once), and “Message Payload Data Type” (here structure). Then, select as “Message Payload Schema” the schema above you’ve created in the “Manage Service Registry” app. The “Message Payload Schema” appears then in the table below the header data you’ve just entered. Expand it and enter aliases for each one of the 3 payload fields of the schema:

Now, scroll down and enter the “Condition Type” (here “Always”), “Action Type” (here “Production Process”), and select first the name of your production process design in the “Available Processes” and then select the automation sequence you’ve created in step 7 (here FR_Enrich_Publish). Lastly, map the respective aliases defined above for the subscribed to message schema to the start parameter sensorID, temperature, and timestamp of the automation sequence. Save, and quick deploy (deploy and activate) the subscription on your production connector.

 

Now, you can use an MQTT client tool to test. We are using MQTTX and publish an example sensor reading to the topic RawData and we can observe that the enriched message is being published by our automation sequence on the correct dynamically computed topic Test/SFC120815/sensor05:

 

Scenario 2: Create a subscription of type “indicator”

 Coming now to the second scenario where the sensor reading is written to tags on an OPC UA server. Here, we are using the three simple tags: Temperature_Celsius, Timestamp, and AssetName (used for sensorID). For simplicity, they are all modeled as a basic data types string. We are using the tool UA Expert to visualize and later overwrite them to trigger the subscription during our test:

For subscriptions of the “indicator” type, you first need to create digital twins in DM’s Production Connectivity Model (PCM) as follows:

  • Create a shop floor system of type OPC UA as a digital twin of your OPC UA server in the “Configure Production Connectivity” app.
  • Create a digital twin of your sensor in the “Manage Assets” app.
  • Map an indicator modeled as part of your digital twin to tags in your OPC UA server in the “Manage Asset Connectivity” app.

I’ll quickly walk you through our configuration. However, for an in-depth explanation of each step we’ll refer to step 4 and 5 in Jianghan Chang’s blog Setting up Shop Floor Connectivity: Connecting your OPC UA Server with SAP Digital Manufacturing.

We are using an OPC UA server, for which we have modeled a digital twin with the name OPC_UA_DEMO for in the “Configure Production Connectivity” app:

 
We have modeled the digital twin FR_Sensor02 for our sensor in the “Manage Assets”:

 It consists of a single structure (here FR_Temperature_Sensor) with three indicators: FR_SensorID, FR_temperature, and FR_timestamp. We have mapped these three indicators to respective tags on our OPC UA server in the “Manage Asset Connectivity” app:

Now, we are ready to create the subscription of the indicator type. We subscribe to all three indicators of the asset FR_Sensor02 because we need all three of them in the action part to pass them on as start parameters of our automation sequence we want to trigger.

We want our subscription to trigger with each new tag written by the sensor to the OPC UA server with a new timestamp. Therefore, we select “On Change” as the trigger condition for the tag “FR_timestamp”.

Scroll down to configure the action. We have chosen “Production Process” as the action type and selected our automation sequence “FR_Enrich_Publish” for “Available Processes” from our production process design created in the earlier step 7. We need to pass on the subscribed indicators to the respective start parameters of the automation sequence. Now, save, and quick deploy (deploy and activate) the subscription.

We are ready to test the subscription by overwriting the timestamp (and optionally the temperature) tags in the UA Expert tool:

We should now observe in MQTTX that this tag has been enriched and published as a message on the dynamically computed broker topic Test/SFC120815/sensor02:

This concludes our blog. You have seen how SAP Digital Manufacturing can flexibly integrate commonly used technologies such as OPC UA, MQTT Brokers and assets acting as Web clients on the shop floor.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Project Validation BAdI (Enterprise...
entry.content:
Hello @jthebat 

Thank you for your inquiry.

Currently, the Project Validation BAdI in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is only available for Key User Extensibility and does not support outbound API calls to external systems. To enable such API calls, the BAdI would need to be released for Developer Extensibility, which is not possible at this time, although you can submit a request to SAP through the Customer Influence programme. For reference, the Purchase Requisition BAdI does support Developer Extensibility and allows such outbound integrations.

Check below helpful SAP Documentation

https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-s4hanacloud-procurement-purchasereq-checks..html

https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-integration-connectivity/http-communication-via-communication-arrangements

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2963059

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to check your SAP Queries for SAP S/4HANA readiness
entry.content:
Hi @gabrielyoung50 ,

technically it is not possible to provide a tool for automated adaptation of custom SAP Queries for S/4HANA. The recommendation is to follow the ATC results and adjust custom SAP Queries as described in the Simplification notes.

Kind Regards,
Olga.
